issues.text: Whether the accused persons suffered prejudice due to the trial court's refusal to grant adjournment for production of defence witnesses?

anchor.surface_text: At the time of arguments in the Trial Court the question of prejudice to the accused persons because of the refusal to grant adjournment for the production of the defence witnesses was raised, but the Court did not consider that any prejudice had resulted to the accused persons who wanted to examine them.

issues.text: Whether there is any ground under Article 136 of the Constitution for the Supreme Court to re-appraise the evidence and interfere with the concurrent findings of the courts below?

anchor.surface_text: under Art. 136 of the Constitution this Court does not normally re-appraise the evidence for considering the credibility of the witnesses as if it is a court of first appeal. Unless the criminal trial is vitiated by some illegality or irregularity of procedure or there is some violation of the rules of natural justice resulting in unfair trial, or unless the judgment has resulted in gross miscarriage of justice, this Court does not as a rule proceed to evaluate the evidence

issues.text: Whether the High Court followed the correct standard laid down by the Supreme Court for dealing with appeals against acquittal?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sarin next submitted that the High Court had not followed the standard laid down by this Court for dealing with the appeals against acquittal and in support of this submission he relied on the decisions of this Court in Sanwat Singh others v. State of Rajasthan  and on an unreported judgment of this Court in Keshav Ganga Ram Navge Anr v. State of Maharashtra 2 . In our opinion, this submission is wholly unfounded.

issues.text: Whether the appeal against acquittal filed in the High Court by the Additional Government Advocate was competent, as he was not the Public Prosecutor?

anchor.surface_text: Finally the counsel laid stress on the submission that the appeal in the High Court was incompetent because the Additional Government Advocate who had presented the appeal was not the Public Prosecutor. The Gazette Notification to which our attention has been drawn shows that Mr. Dubey, the Additional Government Advocate, was notified as Public Prosecutor for the High Court

issues.text: Whether the convictions under Sections 302/34, 302/149, 307/34, 307/149, 148, and 324/34/149 IPC are sustainable warranting no interference under Article 136?

anchor.surface_text: ss. 302/34, 302/149, 307/34 and 307/149 P.C. All these charges relate to the murder of one Karamat Beg Pahalwan s o Mirza Karim Beg at Bombay Bazar Choraha on January 19, 1965, at about 12-30 P.M. and to an attempt on the life of Ikbal Beg s o the deceased Karamat Beg Pahalwan at the same time and place.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this submission is wholly unfounded. The High Court did not ignore the standard laid down by this Court in Sanwat Singhs case 1 . arguments.claim: Convictions under ss. 302/34, 302/149, 148, 324/149 IPC proved based on eye-witness evidence and common intention

anchor.surface_text: The High Court upheld the conviction of Mansoor, Rashid, Ishaq and Yunus and dismissed their appeal. It allowed the State appeal only against the acquittal of Mehmood s o Bhondekhan and convicted him along with four persons convicted by the Trial Court.

holdings.text: No prejudice resulted to the accused persons from the trial court's refusal to grant adjournment for production of defence witnesses, as the belatedly examined defence evidence was wholly unimpressive and did not warrant interference.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of arguments in the Trial Court the question of prejudice to the accused persons because of the refusal to grant adjournment for the production of the defence witnesses was raised, but the Court did not consider that any prejudice had resulted to the accused persons who wanted to examine them. From the record we find that only Mansoor...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial court found no prejudice; Supreme Court permitted examination post-remand but found evidence of Munshikhan unreliable and unimpressive, not altering prosecution case.

holdings.text: Under Article 136, the Supreme Court does not re-appraise evidence or interfere with concurrent findings absent illegality, procedural irregularity, violation of natural justice, or gross miscarriage of justice; no such infirmity shown here.

anchor.surface_text: under Art. 136 of the Constitution this Court does not normally re-appraise the evidence for considering the credibility of the witnesses as if it is a court of first appeal. Unless the criminal trial is vitiated by some illegality or irregularity of procedure or there is some violation of the rules of natural justice resulting in unfair trial, or unless the judgment has resulted in gross miscarriage of justice, this Court does not as a rule proceed to evaluate the evidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reiterates settled practice under Art.136; appellants failed to demonstrate any vitiating factor after review of arguments on witness credibility, FIR, and investigation.

holdings.text: The High Court followed the correct standard laid down by the Supreme Court for dealing with appeals against acquittal, giving due regard to trial court's reasons and providing substantial reasons for reversal where applicable.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this submission is wholly unfounded. The High Court did not ignore the standard laid down by this Court in Sanwat Singhs case 1 . According to that decision the words substantial and compelling reasons for setting aside an order of acquittal used in this Courts earlier decisions

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court applied principles from Sanwat Singh and Sheo Swarup, considered discrepancies pointed by trial court, and gave clear reasons; no deviation shown unlike in Keshav Ganga Ram.

holdings.text: The conviction of Mehmood s/o Bhondekhan under Sections 148 and 149 IPC is sustainable independently of his individual role, as no grave error or miscarriage of justice in High Court's findings.

anchor.surface_text: unless by disregard to the forms of legal process or some violation of the principles of natural justice or otherwise, substantial and grave injustice has been done. Though Art. 136 is couched in widest terms, the practice of this Court is not to interfere on questions of fact except in exceptional cases when the finding is such that it shocks the conscience of the court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 302/34 conviction stands on its own; High Court considered evidence properly without legal error; Mahmood has served sentence.

holdings.text: The appeal against acquittal filed by the Additional Government Advocate was competent, as he was duly notified as Public Prosecutor for the High Court under CrPC Sections 4(1)(i) and 492.

anchor.surface_text: The Gazette Notification to which our attention has been drawn shows that Mr. Dubey, the Additional Government Advocate, was notified as Public Prosecutor for the High Court in respect of the cases arising in the State of Madhya Pradesh. The counsel raised an ingenious argument, namely, that Mr. Dubey could not be considered to be a Public Prosecutor for presenting appeals in the High Court against orders of acquittal,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification covers cases in High Court including acquittal appeals ('case' under CrPC s.417 includes proceedings ending in acquittal); objection not raised below; supported by precedents like Bhiniappa and Bhagwan Das.

holdings.text: The FIR lodged by Iqbal Beg constitutes the first information report; no basis to accept claim of prior report by Mansoor.

anchor.surface_text: We are wholly unable to agree with the counsel that the information lodged by Ikbal Beg was not the F.I.R. and that Mansoor had made the report earlier. The case diary of the police was also subjected to some criticism for the purpose of discrediting the investigation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct rejection based on record review.

holdings.text: Convictions of Mansoor, Rashid, Ishaq, Yunus, and Mehmood s/o Bhondekhan under Sections 302/34, 302/149, 148, and 324/149 IPC are upheld, with no grounds for interference under Article 136.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court upheld the conviction of Mansoor, Rashid, Ishaq and Yunus and dismissed their appeal. It allowed the State appeal only against the acquittal of Mehmood s o Bhondekhan and convicted him along with four persons convicted by the Trial Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings based on reliable eyewitness testimony establishing common intention and unlawful assembly; no perversity or miscarriage warranting Art.136 intervention.
